{include "default_salutation"} –

People across the state are staying home – and the ACLU of Massachusetts is no different. For some, that means watching reruns. For us, it means watching the new docuseries "How to Fix a Drug Scandal."

During the Massachusetts drug lab scandals, thousands of people were wrongfully convicted of drug crimes based on faulty evidence and a government cover-up. In response to these massive scandals, the ACLU of Massachusetts called for mass exoneration to right these wrongful convictions.

The result: more than 61,000 dismissed charges across more than 35,000 cases. Thanks to the heroic work of defense attorneys and the bravery of system-involved people, the ACLU was able to help rectify a historical injustice, as depicted in the new Netflix docuseries, "How to Fix a Drug Scandal." Watch the trailer for "How to Fix a Drug Scandal" and learn more about the ACLU's work on the drug lab cases.

Extraordinary times call for extraordinary solutions: when large groups of people have their rights violated or are put in imminent danger because of the conditions of their confinement, we have a responsibility to adopt bold, sweeping remedies. The same is true during a pandemic.

Last week, we argued in a telephonic hearing of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, where we called for widespread releases to prevent outbreaks of COVID-19 in prisons, jails, and surrounding communities. To flatten the curve and prevent death sentences, we must protect everyone.

In the coming weeks, we hope you can find some comfort with your loved ones, and we hope you can join us in celebrating the heroic work of advocates for justice everywhere.

In Solidarity,

ACLU of {affiliate_name}
